passages.text:
You enter another small basement room, where yet another mesh of bedsheets and greenery cover an emaciated figure.  The air here is vibrantly fetid, moreso than any other rooms.

Every surface is overrun with ferns and dense, dizzying mold patterns.  Thin wires conveying fluids snake around the base of the bed, and infiltrate the sheets at the seams.

passages.text:
Jasper,twisted::Hear that hum?  This room is still powered, like the elevator room.

Jasper,thinking::See those cables?  I think that machine is sustaining this person.

Jasper,surprised::But you know there is life hiding beneath that foliage.  I know you can feel it.

Jasper,thinking::You can feel the clammy misery smothering the lump's skin.  You can feel the mold spores feeding on its nervous system.  

Jasper,head_tilted::You can even sense the bed sores that have fused its back to the mattress.

passages.text:
Jasper,head_tilted::Yes.  You throw the switch, and the flow of electrons and fluids will be cut off.  Brain function, if there is any, will cease, and any corneas attached to the lump will begin to cloud.

Jasper,thinking::Every memory embedded in their synapses will be lost forever.  Their dream of seeing the sun for the first time will be obliterated.

Jasper,twisted::All of this, a mechanical consequence of neurons signalling a contraction in your bicep, allowing you to throw the switch.

Jasper,head_twisted::Are you sure you can live with that?

[[Is there no way to help this thing?  No way to save it?]]
[[I can feel this lump's agony.  It wants to die.]]

passages.text:
You pull on the lever, gently stressing the ligaments contraining your right shoulder to its designated socket.  The connection is severed.  The oxygen, nutrients, and viscous slushes cease flowing.

An electric chill works its way into your brain stem.  Hypoxia sets in, and brain cell death begins to occur.  After only a few minutes, the cerebral cortex disintegrates, like a snowball thrown into an open flame.

Odorous gases escape from the carcass's failing envelope.  Vestigial remnants of muscle contort and contract.  Blood begins to pool in the cadaver's lower portions.

passages.text:
Jasper,head_tilted::The delimiters separating this lump from its environment have disintegrated.  Much of it's epidermis has fused with the bedding, or is being digested by the mold.

Jasper,sad::Only remnants of ligaments and tissue remain, articulating the skeleton, protecting critical organs, and fertilizing the ferns.

Jasper,twisted::We're looking at a breathing carcass.  Any interference is likely to be fatal.  There is no saving it.

passages.text:

[[I just do.  I can feel its painful innervations and consumption and unfed lust.]]

passages.text:
Note::If you're reading this note, I'm dead.

Note::I've written copies of this note, trying to get them out, over and over.  Nothing escapes from down here.

Note::Dr. Anthony Tann is stealing infants and telling the mothers that they are dead.  He and his nurses pump them full of deliriants during delivery, swap the infant out for a corpse, and hands them a certificate declaring that their child was stillborn.

Note::I watched this happen, from the vents in the surgical suite.  I was caught, beaten, and injected with some poison.

Note::Since then, I can't stay awake.  I can't get out of bed.  I can't think.  They don't even bother restraining me. 

Note::The doctor says I have encephalitis.  I've tried to tell them what happened.  They respond by pumping me full of sedatives.  No one is allowed to visit.  No one gets my notes.

Note::I drift in and out.  Every day is shorter than the last.  My swolen brain is about to leak through my ears.

Note::I'm keeping this note locked, tight in my palm, until I expire.  Hopefully no one notices until rigor mortis sets in.

Note::Sneak into Frost's office after hours.  He leaves every day at 6:30.

Note::He has a safe where he keeps those certificates, and keys to experiment rooms.  The safe combo is 38-43-99.  Easy to remember.

Note::Go to the office.  Bust open the safe.  Tell the city what is happening.

Note::Coroner, please give this note to Alex in accounting.

Note::-Vera
